title: Rammed Earth + Hempcrete vs Conventional 2x6 Wood-Framed Wall

LIS.summary: Higher upfront impact offset by long service life and reduced replacement
LIS.relative_position: converges or outperforms over full lifecycle

CPI.summary: Higher upfront cost with lower lifecycle impact per year of service

sections.overview: This comparison evaluates a hybrid wall assembly using rammed earth for structure and hempcrete for insulation against a conventional 2×6 wood-framed wall. Both meet enclosure requirements, but they behave very differently over time.

why_it_scores_this_way.LIS: Rammed Earth + Hempcrete carries higher initial impact due to labor intensity and binder production, but benefits from minimal processing, long service life, and low maintenance. The 2×6 wall begins with lower impact but accumulates lifecycle cost through processed materials, replacements, and maintenance.
why_it_scores_this_way.RIS: Rammed Earth + Hempcrete scores higher due to durability, fire resistance, moisture buffering, indoor air quality, partial carbon storage, and reduced end-of-life waste. The 2×6 wall remains adaptable and familiar but relies more heavily on managed forests and petrochemical insulation.

tradeoffs: 15–30% higher upfront cost in North America

choose_this_when: Longevity and low maintenance are priorities
The project is designed for generational use

sections.takeaway: This comparison highlights a difference in time horizon. Conventional 2×6 framing optimizes for speed and familiarity, while Rammed Earth + Hempcrete optimizes for durability, stability, and long-term impact reduction.
